summary: This is a letter from the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York to Judge Alison J. Nathan regarding the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The government requests permission to redact names and identifying information of third parties from defense filings to protect their privacy, citing the Lugosch test. The defense and the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP take no position on the request.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell; recipient of the government's letter requesting redactions.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced (20 Cr. 330 (AJN)).

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who respectfully submits the letter to the court.

events.title: Court Order on Redaction Requests
events.description: The Court issued an order directing the Government to submit any requests for redaction of information contained in filings regarding the defense's proposed Rule 17(c) subpoena.

events.title: Joint Letter on Redactions
events.description: A joint letter was submitted addressing redactions to documents related to the defense's proposed Rule 17(c) subpoena and objections from Boies Schiller Flexner LLP.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The U.S. Government is seeking to redact names and identifying information of third parties from defense filings in the Ghislaine Maxwell case to protect their privacy.
The request is based on the legal test from the Second Circuit case Lugosch v. Pyramid Co. of Onondaga, balancing public access against privacy interests.
The defense counsel and the law firm Boies Schiller Flexner LLP (BSF), which had filed objections to a defense subpoena, take no position on the government's redaction request.
The document is part of the procedural litigation surrounding evidence and witness disclosure in Maxwell's criminal case.
